docs.snippet: On and off Broadway, in and out of New York, the months ahead are filled with theater openings galore. New works are in the minority; Tom Stoppard, David Mamet, Arthur Miller and Andrew Lloyd Webber are represented, but like Ibsen, O'Neill, Brecht...
docs.lead_paragraph: On and off Broadway, in and out of New York, the months ahead are filled with theater openings galore. New works are in the minority; Tom Stoppard, David Mamet, Arthur Miller and Andrew Lloyd Webber are represented, but like Ibsen, O'Neill, Brecht and Shakespeare, only by successes of the past. Which may be the wave of theater's future. Here is a partial list of productions scheduled in the months ahead. Some are limited runs, and dates, as always, are subject to change.
docs.abstract: Partial list of theater productions on and off Broadway, in and out of New York, planned in months ahead; photo (L)

docs.snippet: THEATER, a medium reliant on flights of imagination, is not exactly a place where precise depictions of real events are common.    But this season, a handful of plays on New York stages and beyond are demonstrating a strong adherence to the facts,...
docs.lead_paragraph: THEATER, a medium reliant on flights of imagination, is not exactly a place where precise depictions of real events are common. But this season, a handful of plays on New York stages and beyond are demonstrating a strong adherence to the facts, with documentary-style texts that have been drawn verbatim from interviews and transcripts.
docs.abstract: Handful of plays on New York stages and beyond this season are demonstrating strong adherence to facts, with documentary-style texts that have been drawn verbatim from interviews and transcripts; they include Anna Deavere Smith's House Arrest, Marc Wolf's Another American: Asking and Telling, Moises Kaufman's The Laramie Project, and Eve Ensler's The Vagina Monologues; photos (M)

headline.main: Bringing the High Drama of Real Life to the Stage

docs.snippet: Derrell Coley did a lot of talking before his fight against Oscar De La Hoya last night at Madison Square Garden. He fumed that he had been ignored. He said he was going to destroy De La Hoya, because De La Hoya had made him wait so long for a sho...
docs.lead_paragraph: Derrell Coley did a lot of talking before his fight against Oscar De La Hoya last night at Madison Square Garden. He fumed that he had been ignored. He said he was going to destroy De La Hoya, because De La Hoya had made him wait so long for a shot. But anger and talk can get a boxer only so far. Ultimately it comes down to talent, skill and punching power as De La Hoya, 27, proved by knocking out Coley, 29, with a crushing left hand to the body at the end of the seventh round before a crowd of 13,814.
docs.abstract: Boxer Oscar De La Hoya knocks out Derrell Coley in seventh round; photos (M)

headline.main: De La Hoya Drops Coley In the 7th

docs.snippet: PRESERVATIONISTS wince when they see how architects in the 1950's renovated majestic old structures like the United States Rubber building at 58th Street and Broadway and the Gorham building at 36th Street and Fifth Avenue.  Such remodelings epito...
docs.lead_paragraph: PRESERVATIONISTS wince when they see how architects in the 1950's renovated majestic old structures like the United States Rubber building at 58th Street and Broadway and the Gorham building at 36th Street and Fifth Avenue. Such remodelings epitomize the era when the marble, granite and bronze of the American renaissance was considered just so much scrap. The architect responsible for those two renovations, Herbert Tannenbaum, is still practicing at age 90 -- and it turns out he didn't like what he did either. ''They told me, 'Do it or we'll get someone else,' '' Mr. Tannenbaum says, recalling how in 1959, although he was committed to the modern style, he had wanted to save the elegant colonnade and sensitive carved marble panels on the Gorham building, which had been designed for the silver company by McKim, Mead & White in 1907. In that year Architectural Record had called the building ''a surprise and a joy.''
docs.abstract: streetscapes/Herbert Tannenbaum on the Gorham and United

headline.main: Streetscapes / Herbert Tannenbaum on the Gorham and United States Rubber Buildings; At 90, Architect Reflects on Remodelings He Regrets

docs.snippet: AMERICANS bought an estimated $14 billion or more of recorded music last year. And music, arguably even more than movies or television, has been the vanguard of the post-World War II American cultural onslaught that has swept through the world.   ...
docs.lead_paragraph: AMERICANS bought an estimated $14 billion or more of recorded music last year. And music, arguably even more than movies or television, has been the vanguard of the post-World War II American cultural onslaught that has swept through the world. So it's odd, in a way, that the annual Grammy Awards show, which was broadcast last week to a domestic audience of over 27 million people, is a kind of musical Land That Time Forgot, a place where, as they used to say at the Holiday Inn, the best surprise is no surprise.

docs.snippet: In a splashy ceremony at Rockefeller Center earlier this month, cameras rolled and an adoring throng applauded as a redheaded, freckle-faced puppet was elevated into the television pantheon.    Surviving cast members, writers and producers of ''Th...
docs.lead_paragraph: In a splashy ceremony at Rockefeller Center earlier this month, cameras rolled and an adoring throng applauded as a redheaded, freckle-faced puppet was elevated into the television pantheon. Surviving cast members, writers and producers of ''The Howdy Doody Show'' -- most in their 80's -- gathered once more to see a bronze star uncovered for the beloved cowboy marionette on NBC-TV's ''Walk of Fame,'' beside those of two flesh-and-blood giants of TV's golden age, Sid Caesar and Milton Berle.
docs.abstract: Heirs of late Rufus Rose, The Howdy Doody Show puppeteer, are battling Detroit Institute of Art over ownership of actual Howdy Doody marionette used on show, which ran from 1947 to 1960; plan to sell puppet and other from show at auction; dispute museum's suit claiming NBC gave Rose custody of puppet with understanding that he would eventually donate it to museum; photos (M)

headline.main: Say, Kids, What Time Is It? Howdy Doody Custody Time!

docs.snippet: REMEMBER when Emma Thompson and Kenneth Branagh seemed destined to become the Lunt and Fontanne of their generation? That ended with their 1995 divorce, of course, but at least we have ''Henry V'' and DEAD AGAIN (1991), their American-made film no...
docs.lead_paragraph: REMEMBER when Emma Thompson and Kenneth Branagh seemed destined to become the Lunt and Fontanne of their generation? That ended with their 1995 divorce, of course, but at least we have ''Henry V'' and DEAD AGAIN (1991), their American-made film noir about reincarnation and murder. Ms. Thompson plays an amnesiac who has recurring dreams that she is a concert pianist murdered in the 1940's. As the investigating detective and the murdered pianist's husband (flashbacks), Mr. Branagh, who directed, does both American and German accents. Sir Derek Jacobi is fabulous as an antiques dealer who dabbles in hypnosis - Saturday at 3 p.m. on Sci Fi.

byline.original: By Anita Gates and Howard Thompson

docs.snippet: In his last fight, against Felix Trinidad, Oscar De La Hoya held back, because he wanted to save something for the finish. He did, but when it was over, he was done as the World Boxing Council welterweight champion. Trinidad lifted his title on a ...
docs.lead_paragraph: In his last fight, against Felix Trinidad, Oscar De La Hoya held back, because he wanted to save something for the finish. He did, but when it was over, he was done as the World Boxing Council welterweight champion. Trinidad lifted his title on a controversial split decision, primarily because De La Hoya retreated in the last four rounds. When De La Hoya climbs into the ring at Madison Square Garden tonight against Derrell Coley in a scheduled 12-round welterweight bout, he cannot afford to hold back, and there really is no reason to do so. If De La Hoya wants to exorcise the ghost of Trinidad, he will eventually have to climb back into the ring against Trinidad, and there is talk that a rematch will happen in June.
docs.abstract: Oscar De La Hoya is not expected to hold back when he climbs into ring against Derrell Coley in scheduled 12-round welterweight out; in his last fight, against Felix Trinidad, De La Hoya did hold back, wanting to save something for finish; that cost him his World Boxing Council welterweight championship following controversial split decision; photo (M)

headline.main: With a Rematch Looming, De La Hoya Won't Retreat

docs.snippet: ASIA    AFGHANISTAN: IMPROVING U.N. RELATIONS -- The top United Nations official in Afghanistan, Francesc Vendrell, said the organization now had offices aiding local government and health services and monitoring human rights in four major cities ...
docs.lead_paragraph: ASIA AFGHANISTAN: IMPROVING U.N. RELATIONS -- The top United Nations official in Afghanistan, Francesc Vendrell, said the organization now had offices aiding local government and health services and monitoring human rights in four major cities -- Kabul, Kandahar, Herat and Mazaar-I-Sharif. He also said women were again working with relief agencies, after being barred from jobs outside their homes. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

docs.snippet: Theater    ''ELMO'S COLORING BOOK,'' the latest ''Sesame Street Live,'' in which Oscar the Grouch, the most colorful character on ''Sesame Street,'' loses his color, turns snow white and becomes alarmingly cheerful. The 90-minute show features a m...
docs.lead_paragraph: Theater ''ELMO'S COLORING BOOK,'' the latest ''Sesame Street Live,'' in which Oscar the Grouch, the most colorful character on ''Sesame Street,'' loses his color, turns snow white and becomes alarmingly cheerful. The 90-minute show features a machine called the Guzzinta 2000, which is fueled by laughter. Today at noon; tomorrow and Sunday at 10:30 a.m., 2 and 5:30 p.m., at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue at 34th Street, Manhattan. Tickets: $16.50 to $25.50. Information: (212) 465-6741. ''MOLLY WIGGLE AND MINNIE SHAKE.'' This 90-minute show features skits by the Paper Bag Players (known as much for their music and dance as for their paper props) that encourage children to wiggle and shake along with the music. Written and directed by Judith Martin, with the assistance of Ted Brackett. Kaye Playhouse, Hunter College, 68th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues. Saturdays and Sundays at 2 p.m. Through March 12. Tickets: $15 and $20. Reservations: (212) 772-4448.
